Idiom: Piti piti zwazo fè nich li
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Proverbial clause; simple present; subject-verb-object structure
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: With patience and persistence, goals are eventually achieved
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Slow and steady progress leads to success
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional Haitian proverb widely used in parenting and schooling
First Example Sentence: Lè ou kontinye etidye chak jou, ou wè piti piti zwazo fè nich li.
Second Example Sentence: Li poko rive kote li vle a, men piti piti zwazo fè nich li.
Third Example Sentence: Pa prese, sonje piti piti zwazo fè nich li.

Idiom: Lè chen gen dan li panse li ka mòde mèt li
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Complex conditional clause with subject-verb agreement
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: People often grow overconfident and challenge authority
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: When people get power, they sometimes forget their place
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common Creole metaphor reflecting hierarchical relationships in Haitian society
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Haitian Cre: /lɛ ʃɛn ʒɛn dã li pãse li ka mɔdɛ mɛt li/
First Example Sentence: Depi li gen ti pouvwa, li vin aji tankou lè chen gen dan li panse li ka mòde mèt li.
Second Example Sentence: Ou sonje jan li te konn soumèt? Gade l kounye a—lè chen gen dan li panse li ka mòde mèt li.
Third Example Sentence: Nou mete l an tèt, epi kounye a li kwè li ka kontwole tout bagay. Lè chen gen dan li panse li ka mòde mèt li.

Idiom: Mare sòs avan ou touye poul
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Prepare fully before starting an important action
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rural Haitian proverb about cooking and readiness
First Example Sentence: Ou vle kite travay ou? Mare sòs avan ou touye poul.

Third Example Sentence: Nou dwe mete estrateji nou an sou pye. Mare sòs avan ou touye poul.

Idiom: Soti pou kont ou tankou kabrit nan tan lapli
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Simile; compound prepositional phrase with comparison
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To go off alone into danger or hardship without preparation
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: To head into a risky situation alone
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to rural imagery of goats braving storms without shelter
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Haitian Cre: /sɔti pu kɔ̃t u tãku kabɣit nã tã lapli/

Second Example Sentence: Li pa gen zanmi, li pa gen estrateji—li jis soti pou kont li tankou kabrit nan tan lapli.
Third Example Sentence: Ou tande avètisman an, men w ap fè tèt di—soti pou kont ou tankou kabrit nan tan lapli.

Idiom: Bay kou bliye, pote mak sonje
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: The person who causes harm forgets, but the victim always remembers
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Widely used Haitian proverb tied to oral tradition and memory
First Example Sentence: Ou ka ri kounye a, men bay kou bliye, pote mak sonje.
Second Example Sentence: Li mete m nan wont devan tout moun. Bay kou bliye, pote mak sonje.
Third Example Sentence: Sa w fè a pa fasil pou mwen bliye—bay kou bliye, pote mak sonje.

Idiom: Chita sou ou, pa di ou pa wè
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Negative imperative; double clause with subject omission
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Don’t ignore what's right in front of you
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: The answer is right under your nose
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Based on Haitian Creole expressions about seeing what's obvious
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Haitian Cre: /ʃita su u, pa di u pa wɛ/
First Example Sentence: Papye a sou tab la, chita sou ou, pa di ou pa wè.
Second Example Sentence: Ou toujou ap chèche repons lan? Chita sou ou, pa di ou pa wè.
Third Example Sentence: Bagay la klè—chita sou ou, pa di ou pa wè.

Idiom: Pale franse pa vle di lespri
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Negative declarative; simple clause with contrastive logic
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Speaking French doesn't mean someone is intelligent
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Fluency in a language doesn’t equal wisdom
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Creole resistance to colonial language prestige and elitism
First Example Sentence: Li ap pale franse tout jounen, men pale franse pa vle di lespri.
Second Example Sentence: Pale franse pa vle di lespri, paske ou ka aprann pawòl san konprann sans.
Third Example Sentence: Yo panse li entelijan paske li pale byen, men pale franse pa vle di lespri.

Idiom: Si ou pa monte, ou pa ka wè lwen
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: If you don’t elevate yourself, you can’t see the bigger picture
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: You need perspective to understand fully
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Draws on mountainous Haitian terrain and metaphor of rising
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Haitian Cre: /si u pa mõte, u pa ka wɛ lwɛ̃/
First Example Sentence: Si ou pa monte, ou pa ka wè lwen—se sak fè edikasyon enpòtan.
Second Example Sentence: Nan vi a, si ou pa monte, ou pa ka wè lwen.
Third Example Sentence: Pou konprann sa k ap pase, ou dwe pran distans. Si ou pa monte, ou pa ka wè lwen.
